name: Euclidean space
explained: Euclidean space is defined as a geometric space characterized by the axioms of Euclidean geometry. Key properties include: 1) The parallel postulate (parallel lines never meet), 2) The sum of angles in a triangle is always 180 degrees, and 3) The existence of a consistent notion of distance and angle. It exists in any number of dimensions, denoted as \( \mathbb{R}^n \) for dimension n, where \( \mathbb{R}^1 \) is a line, \( \mathbb{R}^2 \) is a plane, and \( \mathbb{R}^3 \) is the standard three-dimensional space.
related_conjectures: The foundations of geometry (e.g., independence of the parallel postulate)
Conjectures regarding the dimensionality of the universe
Relationship between Euclidean geometry and physics (e.g., in general relativity)
